--- Derek James <blue5432@...> wrote:
> --- Mitchell Timin <zenguyuno@...> wrote:
> > Thanks for the reply; cleary you put some effort
> > into
> > it.  I am still not able to see its value for
> > scientific work.  
> 
> You don't see any value in being able to share data
> between NEAT implementations written in different
> languages?

I don't see that it's a problem using the original
definition of the data, perhaps written out as a text
file.  
 
> Or having a platform/language-independent way of
> visually rendering networks or run data?

A NEAT network is defined by the original NEAT.  If it
is expressed as a text file if can be read with any
language.  Run data can be anything at all and is not
standardized just by using XML.

> > Don't forget
> > that learning about the various software systems
> you
> > mentioned requires time.  
> 
> There's not really much to learn.  For instance,
> using
> XSL is just a matter of installing Xalan and
> generating the SVG file with a single command-line
> argument.  If you wanted to write your own style
> sheets, then you've have to learn XSL, but there's
> no
> need.

Here are acronyms and phrases that I would have to
learn about, in addition to the precise definition of
XML.  These are copied from the messages in this
thread:

XSD
XSL
SVG
XHTML
XSLT
DOM & Doc. Obj. Model Framework
Xalan
XML dialect

I know nothing about any of these.  I have no idea if
most NEAT users are similar to myself in this respect.

> And of course, if you don't want to do any of this,
> you don't have to.  But I think there is a desire
> among some in the group to develop a standard way of
> representing data that's independent of how it was
> evolved/generated.  If you have a better suggestion
> for such a format than XML, please let us know.

I would prefer a plain text format, similar to that
which Ken has shown in one of his messages.  Of course
you can take XML and remove all of the angle brackets
and other extraneous symbols and you will get one
possible text representation.

Of course, I am commenting as an interested outsider,
since I am not currently running NEAT.

=====
Mitchell Timin
